bibl.title: Letter from [Laura Armistead Carter] to Frederick F. Russell, August 16, 1928

div1.p: [Carter] asks if Russell can supply bibliographical references to unpublished reports of the International Health Division of the Rockefeller Foundation.

div1.head: Letter from [Laura Armistead Carter] to Frederick F. Russell, August 16, 1928

opener.dateline:
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
August 16, 1928.

div1.p: Your good letter of August 9th. was read with much interest.

I am extremely sorry about the fever at Rio. As you say, it is
“Another unfortunate incident to arouse interest in yellow fever.”

The work on the bibliography of Father's book is being pushed
harder than ever, if that be possible:--Miss Brown and I getting to
the Library of the Surgeon General between 7 and 8 A. M. and the former
frequently staying until 10 P. M. This latter is beyond me, although I
frequently work at home at night. Thanks to the very welcome change o in
temperature of last Saturday, one can stand these long hours with much less
distress than heretofore. Unfortunately long hours are needed at this
stage of the work, if you are to get the MSS according to our tentative
schedule: This because it takes so much time to find the place of publi-
cation of some of Father's medical references--especially those appearing
in periodicals. Of course, its perfectly “plain sailing” once the right
publication has been found. In this connection, both Mr. Neumann and Mr.
Toepper have been most kind and helpful, while Miss Brown has been indefa-
tigable and most ingenious in tracing obscure references to their proper
“locale.” By “obscure,” I mean those on which we have insufficient data.

In the above connection, I should be very grateful if some member
of your staff could give me more specific data on the enclosed list of
references from Father's MSS. This would save much time, the more so as
I believe that some of these references come from unpublished (and possi-
bly confidential) reports, so that we might lose waste considerable time in looking
for them in the Index Medicus etc. I have long since written personally
to Dr. Connor and several other people, in order to get exact bibliographic
data on references to articles, not only by themselves, but concerning other
-2-
authors of whose publications they should be cognizant. No replies as yet,
although I had hoped to hear long since. Is Connor in Brazil? That, of
course, would account for my not having yet heard from him.

I am still expecting to go over to Baltimore in September to work
with Dr. Frost. Hope to be able to sub-let this apartment before I leave as
it would be a calamity to have it on my hands while working in Baltimore.
However, the completion of the work on the book is my one and only consid-
eration and just as soon as the bibliographic material is ready I shall
take it to Baltimore.

I need not tell you under what delightful auspices Miss Brown and
I are working at the Library of the Surgeon General of the Army nor how
much the courtesies and facilities extended us by Colonel Ashburn and his
staff are appreciated. The heat has been the only drawback and I hope and
trust that it is now too late in the summer for any more such weather as
we have suffered from in the past.
div1.closer:
With best wishes to yourself and the work,
Most truly yours, 1 enclosure.
Dr. Frederick F. Russell,
Director,
International Health Division
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
